description: An object representing a single phoneme in a language, and its allophones.
title: Phoneme

$eref.description: An object representing a single phoneme in a language, and its allophones.
$eref.title: Phoneme

___target1.description: For diphthongs or triphthongs, this should be a Phoneme object representing the features of the first target in the pronunciation of the diphthong/triphthong.
___target1.title: Dipthong / Triphthong Target 1

___type.description: The type of object. Must be set to `Phoneme`.
___type.title: Type

___tags.description: A set of tags for this phoneme
___tags.title: Tags

___voicing.description: Whether the phoneme is voiced, voiceless, or partially voiced
___voicing.title: Voicing

___backness.description: Describes the backness of a vowel.
___backness.title: Backness

___target3.description: For triphthongs, this should be a Phoneme object representing the features of the third target in the pronunciation of the triphthong.
___target3.title: Triphthong Target 3

___target2.description: For diphthongs or thriphthongs, this should be a Phoneme object representing the features of the second target in the pronunciation of the diphthong/triphthong.
___target2.title: Dipthong / Triphthong Target 2

___allophones.description: A list of allophones of this phoneme, following the same format as for Phoneme objects.
___allophones.title: Allophones

items.description: An allophone of this phoneme. Allophones are formatted exactly the same way as Phoneme objects.
items.title: Allophone

___tone.description: An abstract representation of the tone of this phoneme, e.g. `H`, `13`, `falling`, etc.
___tone.title: Tone

___features.description: A list of the phonemically distinctive features of this Phoneme. These are what are listed under `diacritics` in the IPA chart. For example, if a language distinguishes between a palatalized `/t/` and a plain `/t/`, the first should include the feature `palatalized` and the second `plain` (or no features). Note that most features are also a manner of articulation as well, so it up to the linguist to decide when a given phonetic detail is a manner, or when it is a feature (i.e. a diacritic). For example, a language might distinguish phonemically between a palatal plosive `/c/` and a palatalized plosive `/tʲ/`. The first would list `palatal` as its place of articulation, while the second would list `palatalized` as a distinctive feature. Do not include features here if they are already used for manner, unless your analysis is that this feature is *both* a manner and a feature of this phoneme, e.g. a palatalized palatal stop. This field is used primarily for consonants, but may also apply to vowels as well (e.g. the `close` and `open` features).
___features.title: Features

items.description: A phonemically distinctive feature, taken from the set of features (diacritics) in the IPA chart.
items.title: Feature

___manner.description: The manner of articulation, for consonants. Only one manner of articulation may be listed. Additional manners must be listed under the `features` attribute. For example, the lateral fricative `ɬ` might have a `manner` set to `fricative` and a feature `lateral`, or vice versa, depending on the linguist’s analysis.
___manner.title: Manner of Articulation

___place.description: The place of articulation for consonants. Only one place of articulation may be listed. Additional places must be listed as features under the `features` attribute. For example, a palatalized alveolar `/tʲ/` would list `alveolar` under `manner`, and `palatalized` under `features`.
___place.title: Place of Articulation

___rounding.description: A description of the roundedness of a vowel. Only one type of roundedness may be listed. Rounded vowels may be listed as simply `rounded`, or more specifically as `protruded` or `compressed`.
___rounding.title: Rounding

___references.description: A collection of bibliographic references about this phoneme
___references.title: Bibliographic References

items.description: A bibliographic reference
items.title: Bibliographic Reference

___length.description: The length of this phoneme, whether for consonants (e.g. `short` vs. `geminate`) or vowels
___length.title: Length

___ipa.description: The IPA representation of this phoneme / allophone. Transcriptions of phonemes should contain only the phonemically contrastive sounds. Transcriptions of allophones should contain only the regularly-conditioned alternations.
___ipa.title: IPA Transcription

___airstream.description: The airstream mechanism used to pronounce this Phoneme. `Pulmonic` (egressive) sounds are created by pushing air out of the lungs. `Ejective` sounds are glottalic egressive sounds where the air column is compressed by upward movement of the glottis. `Implosive` sounds are glottalic ingressives where air is pulled in by a downward movement of the glottis. `Click` sounds, i.e. lingual / velaric ingressive sounds, pull air in with a downward movement of the tongue.
___airstream.title: Airstream Mechanism

items.description: A Note about this Phoneme
items.title: Note

___target1.description: For diphthongs or triphthongs, this should be a Phoneme object representing the features of the first target in the pronunciation of the diphthong/triphthong.
___target1.title: Dipthong / Triphthong Target 1

___type.description: The type of object. Must be set to `Phoneme`.
___type.title: Type

$eref.description: A tag is a piece of metadata that can be applied to almost any DLx object. The tags object contains a set of tags for this resource as pairs of attributes and values. For example, a researcher might tag a suffix with the attribute `person`, and a value of `3`, to indicate that the particular suffix is 3rd Person. If no value is needed, the value may also be set to `true` or `false` (but not `null`), however users are encouraged to use both attribute and value for every tag, since this helps identify the larger category that the tag value belongs to. Note: The Tags object does not have a `type` property.

additionalProperties.description: A single tag, as an attribute-value pair.
additionalProperties.title: Tag

$eref.title: Tags

$eref.$comment: This is a top-level database object
$eref.title: Bibliographic Reference

___lastName.description: The last name(s) of this author
___lastName.title: Last Name

___firstName.description: The first name(s) of this author
___firstName.title: First Name

___year.description: The year this item was published. Use a positive integer for AD / ACE, and a negative integer for BC / BCE.
___year.title: Year

___type.description: The type of object. Must be set to `BibliographicReference`.
___type.title: Type

___authors.description: An array of authors for this Reference
___authors.title: Authors

items.description: A Person object representing an author
items.title: Author

___editors.description: An array of editors for this Reference
___editors.title: Editors

items.description: A Person object representing an editor
items.title: Editor

___publisher.description: The name of the publisher of this reference, or the institution where it was published
___publisher.title: Publisher (or Institution)

___series.description: The series in which this publication was published
___series.title: Series

___edition.description: The edition of this Reference, formatted as an integer
___edition.title: Edition

___volume.description: The volume number for this publication
___volume.title: Volume

___pages.description: The page numbers of this Reference
___pages.title: Pages

___publication.description: The publication where this item was published
___publication.title: Publication

___translators.description: An array of translators for this Reference
___translators.title: Translators

items.description: A Person object representing a translator
items.title: Translator (Person)

___doi.description: The Digtial Object Identifier (DOI) for this publication. This should be just the DOI itself, not a URL, and should not include the `doi:` prefix (e.g. `10.1075/cal.20.02hie` not `https://doi.org/10.1075/cal.20.02hie` or `doi:10.1075/cal.20.02hie`).
___doi.title: Digital Object Identifier (DOI)

___id.description: A unique database identifier for this Reference
___id.title: ID

___city.description: The city in which this reference was published
___city.title: City

items.description: A bibliographic reference
items.title: Bibliographic Reference

examples.text: Msemaji huyu ni Janet Kerubo Momanyi.
Box turtles are known for eating strawberries.

$eref.description: A note about this resource. Notes may also include `type` and `language` attributes.
$eref.title: Note

___language.description: A language code or language name of the language that this note is written in
___language.title: Note Language

___dateModified.description: The date and optionally time that this note was last modified
___dateModified.title: Date Modified

___text.description: The text of the note itself
___text.title: Note Text

___type.description: The type of object. Must be set to `Note`.
___type.title: Type

___tags.description: A set of tags that apply to this Note. Useful for tagging notes that need review or responses, or marking a note as resolved.
___tags.title: Tags

___dateCreated.description: The date and optionally time that this note was created
___dateCreated.title: Date Created

___noteType.description: The type of Note. Required for notes on Lexemes.
___noteType.title: Note Type

___source.description: The name or initials of the person who is the source of the information in this Note. This is not necessarily the person who wrote it. For example, a linguist could make a note based on something that a speaker reports, in which case the speaker should be listed as the source.
___source.title: Source (Person)

items.description: A Note about this Phoneme
items.title: Note
